column1: Jakobstad (Finnish: Pietarsaari) is a town and municipality in Ostrobothnia
column2: Finland. The town has a population of 19
column3: 168 (31 July 2020) and covers a land area of 88.31 square kilometres (34.10 sq mi). The population density is 217.05 inhabitants per square kilometre (562.2/sq mi). Neighbour municipalities are Larsmo

column1: The Swedish name literally means Jacob's City or Jacob's Town
column2: in reference to Jacob De la Gardie. The town was founded at the old harbour of the parish Pedersöre and this name lives on in the Finnish name of the municipality

column1: The town was founded in 1652 by Ebba Brahe
column2: the widow of the military commander Jacob De la Gardie
column3: and was granted city privileges by Queen Christina of Sweden. The town was founded at the old harbour of the parish Pedersöre. Pedersöre remains an independent municipality neighbouring Jakobstad.

column1: The city grew slowly at first
column2: with the authorities scarcely promoting any growth. In 1680 the inhabitants were ordered to relocate to the cities of Karleby (Kokkola)
column4: but the order was rescinded. Wars also contributed to the slow growth
column5: and the city was invaded by Russian troops twice during the Greater Wrath
column6: and large parts of the town were burnt to the ground. A majority of the inhabitants fled the city. While those with means moved across the sea to the Swedish side
column7: others took shelter in the forest or in the archipelago. Many were captured or killed. During the 1720s
column8: some of the previous inhabitants returned
column9: while newcomers also added to the population. The subsequent decades were finally marked by a period of growth
column10: and the current church was built in 1731.

column1: The economic foundation was laid in the mid 18th century
column2: with tar manufacturing and tobacco packaging at its centre. Trade started to develop rapidly in Jakobstad as of 1765
column3: when the cities along the Finnish shore of the Gulf of Bothnia were granted privileges by the Swedish crown to trade directly with foreign countries. This also led to shipbuilding becoming a major activity in Jakobstad. The first ships to sail with goods to foreign countries were the galeas Jacobstads Wapen and the brig Enigheten. Trade and shipbuilding made Jakobstad a wealthy city
column4: and a notable businessman of that time was the merchant and shipbuilder Adolf Lindskog
column5: who also became one of the richest men in Finland.

column1: The early 19th century was a time of upheaval
column2: which saw the 1808–1809 war between Sweden and Russia
column3: as well as a devastating fire in 1835 that destroyed approximately half of the city. Despite this
column6: a matchstick factory and several banks were founded after 1850. In 1859
column7: the merchant and shipowner Peter Malm started a steam powered sawmill
column8: which was only the second such installation in Finland. The Crimean War was a major setback to shipping industry
column9: as the British navy puts up an effective blockade and the shipping fleet in Jakobstad during the Åland War was reduced from 26 ships to 9.

column1: Notable businessmen in the 19th century were Otto Malm and Wilhelm Schauman
column2: the latter founding a chicory (coffee substitute) factory in Jakobstad in 1883. This moment in time is usually considered as the start of industrialization in Jakobstad. In 1900
column3: the Strengberg tobacco factory was the largest employer in Jakobstad.

column1: An artillery school was located in Jakobstad during the Finnish civil war. During World War II
column2: the city was bombed once by Soviet bomber planes
column3: causing a few casualties. Up until the 1960s
column4: the town was overwhelmingly Swedish speaking
column5: but as a consequence of industrial expansion in the 1960s and 1970s
column6: the need for additional work force caused a large influx of Finnish speakers. The town remains bilingual with 56% being Swedish and 40% Finnish speakers.

At the end of November a chamber music festival called Rusk is held annually in Pietarsaari/Jakobstad. At the heart of this festival embracing superb chamber music and various other genres of the arts is the Schauman Hall in the centre of town
column2: but the events also spread out into the surrounding urban environment.

column1: Jakobstad City Hall (Swedish: Jakobstads rådhus) is a historic building in the city which was completed in 1875. The current look of the building dates from 1890.
Jakobstad is the home of the galeas Jacobstads Wapen
column2: a full-scale replica built between 1987 and 1992
column3: based on the original 1755 drawings by Swedish naval architect Fredrik Henrik af Chapman [1]

column1: Jakobstad - Pietarsaari Museum is the main museum in the city
column2: concentrating on maritime and ship building history

column1: The Arctic museum Nanoq is located outside Jakobstad.
Chicorymuseum is the only chicorymuseum in Finland. In the former chicory factory from the 19th century visitors can familiarize themselves with the production of chicory
column2: get acquainted with Wilhelm Schaumans early industrial career and also experience authentic old factory conditions. The museum in Pietarsaari will also offer art exhibitions and other events.

column1: The botanical garden Skolparken (literally "the school park")
column2: with approximately 1
column4: is renowned both as one of the most northerly botanical gardens in the world and for its classical park architecture. The foundation was laid in 1915 and the park was completed in 1932. The funding was provided by the Schauman family
column5: who wanted to honour the memory of Elise and Viktor Schauman. The park was designed by the prominent Finnish garden architect Bengt Schalin.

column1: Skata is a protected residential area close to the city centre which dates from 1783. Up until the late 19th century
column2: Skata was home primarily to sailors and their families. As of the 1890s
column3: it transformed into a mainly working class area
column4: providing housing to a large part of the work force employed by the Strengberg tobacco factory.

column1: The town's football team FF Jaro currently plays in Ykkönen
column2: the second league in Finland. The woman's league football club FC United has been very successful over the years.
